metadata.title: Monocyte-derived Prostaglandin E2 inhibits antigen-specific cutaneous immunity during ageing 2

abstract.text: 40 words): 23 Inflammation resulting from tissue injury blocks antigen-specific cutaneous immunity during 24 ageing. Monocytes recruited to the skin inhibit TRM function through COX2-derived 25 prostaglandin E2 production. Blocking inflammation and resulting prostaglandin E2 26 production with a p38-MAP kinase inhibitor significantly enhances cutaneous antigen-27 specific responses. 28 ES Chambers et al 2 | P a g e Abbreviations: 29 CBA -cytometric bead array 30 CRP -C reactive protein 31 COX2 -Cyclooxygenase 2 32 DC -Dendritic Cell 33 LPS -Lipopolysaccharide 34 ILT -Immunoglobulin-like transcript 35 p38-MAPK -p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase 36 PD-L -Programme-death ligand 37 PGE2 -Prostaglandin E2 38 PV -perivascular infiltrate 39 SASP -senescence associated secretory phenotype 40 Tregs -T regulatory cells 41 TRM -T resident-memory cells 42 VZV -Varicella Zoster Virus 43 ES Chambers et al 3 | P a g e Abstract:

44 Ageing results in a decline in immune function. We showed previously that healthy older 45 humans (>65 years old) have reduced antigen-specific cutaneous immunity to varicella 46 zoster virus (VZV) antigen challenge. This was associated with p38 MAP kinase driven 47 inflammation that was induced by mild tissue injury caused by the injection of the antigen 48 itself. Here we show that non-specific injury induced by injection of air or saline into the skin 49 of older adults recruits CCR2 + CD14 + monocytes by CCL2 produced by senescent 50 fibroblasts. These monocytes reduced TRM proliferation via secretion of prostaglandin E2 51 (PGE2). Pre-treatment with a p38-MAPK inhibitor (Losmapimod) in older adults in vivo 52 significantly decreased CCL2 expression, recruitment of monocyte into the skin, COX2 53 expression and PGE2 production. This enhanced the VZV response in the skin. Therefore, 54 local inflammation arising from interaction between senescent cells and monocytes leads to 55 immune decline in the skin during ageing, a process that can be reversed. 56 ES Chambers et al 4 | P a g e Introduction: 57 Immunity decreases during ageing as evidenced by the increase in susceptibility to 58 infections such as pneumonia and influenza, re-activation of latent infections such as 59 varicella zoster virus (VZV; herpes zoster or shingles), decreased vaccine efficacy and 60 increased incidence of cancer (Ciabattini et al., 2018; Diffey and Langtry, 2005; Gavazzi and 61 Krause, 2002). A key challenge is to identify mechanisms that can be manipulated to boost 62 immunity and reduce morbidity and mortality in older individuals. Low grade systemic 63 inflammation, termed inflammageing is characterised by high serum levels of the 64 inflammatory cytokines IL-6, IL-1β, TNFα and C reactive protein (CRP) (Franceschi et al., 65 2017). Elevated levels of inflammatory proteins are a strong predictor for frailty and mortality 66 (Dinh et al., 2019; Furman et al., 2017). However, it is not clear how inflammageing inhibits 67 antigen-specific immunity during ageing. Mechanisms that contribute to inflammageing may 68 include increased gut permeability and subsequent lipopolysaccharide (LPS; a TLR4 ligand) 69 leakage (Kim et al., 2016; Thevaranjan et al., 2017), increased presence of damage-70 associated molecular pattern molecules (DAMPs) and increased visceral fat that can 71 activate mononuclear phagocytes (Franceschi et al., 2017). In addition, senescent non-72 lymphoid cells in tissues (such as fibroblasts) can also secrete many inflammatory proteins 73 as part of the senescence associated secretory phenotype (SASP) (Campisi, 2013; Freund 74 et al., 2010; Hall et al., 2016). 75 We previously identified reduced antigen-specific cutaneous recall responses in healthy old 76 compared to young donors in vivo (Agius et al., 2009; Akbar et al., 2013; Vukmanovic-Stejic 77 et al., 2008; Vukmanovic-Stejic et al., 2018). This difference was not due to decreased 78 numbers or the responsiveness of antigen-specific circulating or skin resident-memory T 79 cells (TRM) (Vukmanovic-Stejic et al., 2015)

, suggesting that there were changes in the skin 80 microenvironment that inhibited antigen-specific T cell function in these subjects. One such 81 change was the propensity to exhibit amplified inflammation in response to mild tissue injury 82 in the skin after saline-injection, that was not observed in young subjects (Vukmanovic-Stejic 83 et al., 2018). There was a direct association between the propensity to exhibit inflammation 84 in older subjects and the decreased response to VZV antigen challenge in the skin since 85 short-term systemic treatment with an oral anti-inflammatory drug (Losmapimod; p38 86 mitogen-activated protein kinase [p38 MAPK] inhibitor) significantly increased the cutaneous 87 VZV response (Vukmanovic-Stejic et al., 2018). A crucial unanswered question was the 88 mechanism by which inflammation inhibited immunity in vivo. 89

Here we show that CCR2 + CD14 + monocytes are recruited into the skin of older donors after 90 saline, air or VZV antigen injection. These monocytes are recruited by in response to CCL2 91 ES Chambers et al 5 | P a g e secreted by senescent dermal fibroblasts. The infiltrating monocytes have increased 92 expression of cyclooxygenase 2 (COX2) and can inhibit TRM proliferation in vitro via 93 production of prostaglandin E2 (PGE2). Blockade of systemic inflammation using a p38 94 MAPK inhibitor (Losmapimod) in older adults significantly reduced CCL2 production from 95 senescent fibroblasts and recruitment of monocytes into the skin after injection in vivo. In 96 addition, Losmapimod treatment significantly reduced COX2 expression and PGE2 97 production confirming that p38 MAPK signalling is upstream of COX2 (Dean et al., 1999; 98 Guan et al., 1998). This significantly enhanced VZV-specific T cell proliferation in the skin. 99

This identifies a broad mechanism by which inflammation may inhibit immunity in many 100 different tissues during ageing. A key observation is that this decline in immune 101 responsiveness may be reversible in humans by the shot-term blockade of systemic 102 inflammation in vivo. 103 ES Chambers et al 6 | P a g e Materials and Methods: 104 Study design: 105 The investigation of healthy young versus old subjects was approved by the Ethics 106 Committee Queen's Square (London) and by institutional review board (UCL R&D). Volunteers were injected intradermally with VZV skin test 282 antigen in one arm (for the clinical score) and with saline (0.9% NaCl) in the other arm as a 283 control. 5mm biopsies were collected from the injection sites 6 hours post-injection and 284 compared to biopsies of normal (unmanipulated) skin ( Figure 1A ). We showed previously 285 that mononuclear phagocyte numbers were increased at the site of saline injection in old but 286 not young subjects and that this accumulation was negatively correlated with the magnitude 287 of antigen-specific responses induced in the contralateral arm of the same individual 288 To enumerate the changes in monocyte numbers following saline injection we assessed 293 paired samples and expressed data as delta change from normal skin. This was to mitigate 294 against inter-personal variation in the magnitude of responses observed (Supplementary 295 Figure 2A ). CD14 is expressed by the majority of peripheral blood monocytes (classical and 296 intermediate). There was a significant increase in CD14 + cells in saline injected skin at 6 297 hours post-injection ( Figure 1B and 1C) . We next investigated the expression of CCR2, a 298 chemokine receptor for CCL2, which is highly expressed by CD14 + monocytes (Patel et al., 299 2017; Ziegler-Heitbrock et al., 2010). There was a significant increase in number of 300 CD14 + CCR2 + cells in saline injected skin as compared to normal skin in old but not young 301 subjects ( Figure 1C ). This response to saline was transient as by 24 hours post-injection 302 there is was no significant difference in frequency of monocytes between normal and saline-303 injected skin (Supplementary Figure 2C) . Multiparametric flow cytometry analysis of normal 304 and saline biopsies, using our previously published panel to identify mononuclear 305 phagocytes (Vukmanovic-Stejic et al., 2018), confirmed that there was a significant increase 306 in CD14 + and CCR2 + CD14 + cells in old saline-injected skin ( Figure 1D ). 307

To investigate whether this inflammatory response after saline injection in older humans was 308 due to sodium chloride itself or a response to needle injury, we performed intradermal 309 injections with the same volume of air instead of saline (20μl). Air injection also induced a 310 significant increase in the number of monocytes at the site of air challenge in old but not 311 young subjects compared to normal skin in both groups (Supplementary Figure 2B) . The 312 accumulation of monocytes was also observed at six hours at the site of VZV injection in old 313 but not young adults ( Figure 1E ). Taken together these data suggest that old subjects have 314 a heightened inflammatory response to mild skin injury that is not observed in young 315

We previously showed that >85% of older individuals have a low VZV response, clinical 317 score between 0-3, while >85% of young individuals have a score of between 3-10 (Agius et 318 al., 2009; Vukmanovic-Stejic et al., 2015). However, a small proportion of older people 319 (~15%) show good cutaneous VZV responsiveness (score 3-10), a group we designated as 320 'old responders'. To assess whether the CD14 + monocyte infiltration was a characteristic of 321 all aged individuals or only those with reduced VZV-specific immunity, we investigated the 322 infiltration of these cells after saline in old VZV responders (red circles) and low responders 323 (filled circles). Old responders to VZV exhibited a similar low extent of CD14 + monocyte 324 infiltration to younger adults (black squares). However, the majority of older donors with a 325 low clinical score (filled circles) had elevated infiltration of these cells. When all the data was 326 combined there was a significant negative correlation between the fold change in CD14 + 327 monocytes in response to saline challenge and the VZV clinical score (R=-0.38 and p=0.04; 328 Figure 1E ). Collectively this indicates that the early recruitment of monocytes to the site of 329 skin challenge in old people was associated with decreased antigen-specific immunity. 330 331 Senescent stromal cells contribute to recruitment of monocytes in the old. 332

We hypothesised that the increase in CD14 + cells in the skin was due to recruitment of 333 circulating monocytes, since CCR2 + expression supported the possibility of recruitment in 334 response to CCL2. The alternative explanation that proliferation of local tissue-resident 335 macrophages (identified as CD163 + ) was not observed (data not shown). This is in line with 336 murine studies showing dermal macrophages are constantly replenished from the monocyte 337 pool (Tamoutounour et al., 2013) . We first investigated the activation status of the dermal 338 endothelium to determine whether it was permissive for monocyte recruitment. CD62E, also 339 known as E-selectin, was used as a marker of activated endothelium as it binds to sialylated 340 carbohydrates expressed on leukocytes and facilitates their extravasation into the tissue. 341

Saline-injected skin of old but not young adults exhibited increased CD62E expression on 342 the CD31 + endothelium when compared to normal skin (Figure 2A and B). Furthermore, 343 transcriptional analysis of skin biopsies indicated that there was increased expression of a 344 range of genes encoding monocyte chemoattractants including CCL2, CXCL10, CXCL2 and 345 CXCL1 in old but not young saline-injected skin as compared to normal skin ( Figure 2C ).

body_text.section: Figure 7: Losmapimod treatment increases VZV induced T cell responses in the skin

body_text.text: In older adults the mild damage induced by injection (of air, saline or VZV) results in production of CCL2 from senescent fibroblasts and recruitment of monocytes into the skin 6 hours post injection. The recruited monocytes inhibit TRM proliferation via upregulation of COX2 and subsequent production of the lipid mediator Prostaglandin E2 (PGE2). The treatment of older adults with the p38 MAPK inhibitor, Losmapimod, results in reduced CCL2 production from the senescent fibroblasts and reduced monocyte infiltration. In addition, p38 MAPK is upstream of COX2 signalling, therefore the treatment with Losmapimod also inhibits COX2 upregulation and reduced PGE2 production. This significantly increases the T cell response to VZV in the skin of older subjects

FIGREF3.text: and F). It is known that fibroblasts can 353 produce CCL2 (Pereira et al., 2019). We and others have shown that there are increased 354 numbers of senescent fibroblasts in the skin of older humans (Dimri et al., 1995; Pereira et 355 al., 2019; Ressler et al., 2006) and CCL2 is a known component of the senescence 356 associated secretory phenotype (SASP)(Campisi, 2013). Indeed, using p16 as a marker of 357 senescence we found that FSP1 + p16 + fibroblasts were the main source of CCL2 after saline 358 injection of old donors (Figure 2Gand H). Senescent fibroblasts made up 61.8% of 359 CCL2 + FSP1 + cells in normal skin which increased to 70.7% in saline-injected skin (data not 360 shown). Although some non-senescent fibroblast evidently expressed CCL2, our previous 361 data showed that senescent fibroblasts produce significantly more CCL2 than the non-362 senescent fibroblasts (Pereira et al., 2019). Therefore, the early production of SASP-related 363 mediators by senescent fibroblasts after saline injection (including CCL2) may lead to the 364 recruitment of inflammatory monocytes to the site of skin challenge. This interaction between 365 senescent cells and monocyte recruitment is supported indirectly by the significant 366 correlation between the number of senescent fibroblasts present in the skin and the extent of 367 CD14 + monocyte infiltration after saline injection (Fig. 2I). 368 369 Monocytes inhibit TRM proliferation through production of Prostaglandin E2. 370 We next investigated the mechanisms by which the recruitment of monocytes reduced 371 antigen-specific immunity in old subjects. We found that Losmapimod pre-treatment was 484 associated with a significant increase in CD4 + (Figure 7C,7D) and CD8 + (Figure 7F, 7G) T 485 cell infiltration into the skin 7 days after VZV injection. The increased number of CD4 + and 486 CD8 + T cells in perivascular infiltrates was associated with an increased proliferation of 487 these cells in situ indicated by Ki67 expression (Figures 7E and H) (Vukmanovic-Stejic et al., 2015). Taken together our data show that short-term blockade of inflammation using the p38 489 MAP kinase inhibitor Losmapimod can significantly enhance the cutaneous immune 490 response to antigen challenge in older adults.Discussion:Furthermore, older adults who had the greatest tendency to mount inflammatory responses 494 after mild tissue injury induced by saline injection had the lowest response to recall response495 to VZV antigen challenge in the skin (Vukmanovic-Stejic et al., 2018). This suggested that 496 increased propensity to exhibit inflammatory responses leads to inhibition of VZV-specific T 497 cell responses in the skin. The fact that the temporary blockade of inflammation in these old 498 individuals with a p38-MAPK inhibitor in vivo enhanced the response to VZV antigen 499 challenge in the skin supports this contention (Vukmanovic-Stejic et al., 2018). However, the 500 source of inflammation in the skin of older subjects or the mechanism by which the 501 inflammation inhibited TRM cell function was not known. 502 We now show that senescent fibroblasts in the skin of old subjects secrete an array of 503 chemokines including CCL2 in response to tissue injury, such as those induced by injecting 504 saline, VZV or air. This leads to recruitment of inflammatory monocytes into the skin that 505 inhibit skin TRM activation in part by secreting lipid mediators such as PGE2 via a COX2-506 dependant pathway. However, short-term systemic p38-MAPK blockade induced by treating 507 old donors with Losmapimod, leads to significantly reduced CCL2 (and other chemokine) 508 production by senescent fibroblasts, reduced monocyte infiltration and reduced COX2 and 509 PGE2 expression in response to injection of saline or VZV antigens. This results in 510 significant improvement of VZV-specific cutaneous T cell responses (Figure 8). Therefore, 511 p38-MAPK inhibition can act by significantly reducing the recruitment of inflammatory 512 monocytes into the skin and also by inhibiting the function of those that still manage to 513 extravagate into the tissue. 514 Ageing leads to the accumulation of senescent cells that is observed in many tissues 515 including the skin (Pereira et al., 2019; Ressler et al., 2006); therefore, the recruitment of 516 inflammatory monocytes in response to signals from senescent fibroblasts may contribute to 517 age-related decreased immunity in other organs as well as the skin. CCL2 is involved in the 518 recruitment of monocytes into the skin and it is a component of the SASP (Pereira et al., 519 2019). The significant correlation between the number of senescent fibroblasts that were 520 present in the skin before injection and the extent of CD14 + monocyte infiltration indirectly 521 supports the interaction between these cells. Although the abundance of senescent cells 522 increases in the skin during ageing (Dimri et al., 1995; Pereira et al., 2019; Ressler et al., 523 2006) there is no overt expression of inflammatory mediators in un-manipulated skin of old 524 subjects (Vukmanovic-Stejic et al., 2015). This suggests that at the steady state, the 525 propensity to mount inflammatory responses including the SASP is inhibited in this tissue. In 526 support of this idea there are increased numbers of Foxp3 + T regulatory cells (Tregs) and 527 increased expression of the inhibitory receptor PD-1 by cutaneous TRM cells, which may 528 contribute to the control of inflammation in this tissue I older individuals (Vukmanovic-Stejic 529 et al., 2008; Vukmanovic-Stejic et al., 2015). One possibility is that Tregs may inhibit the 530 secretion of inflammatory mediators by senescent tissue stromal cells and this requires 531 further investigation. The breakdown of homeostasis induced by tissue injury, may override 532 pre-existing inhibitory processes and allow the secretion of SASP-related factors leading to 533 the subsequent events that we have described 534 We found that skin infiltrating monocytes secrete PGE2 via a COX2 dependent pathway. 535 PGE2 has disparate roles in immune responses as it has been shown to be pro-536 inflammatory (causing oedema formation and pain) as well as contributing to resolution of 537 inflammation (Kalinski, 2012). Here we show that PGE2 produced by COX2 expressing 538 inflammatory monocytes inhibits T cell proliferation in vitro and may directly inhibit antigen-539 specific TRM activation in the skin. PGE2 has been shown previously to directly inhibit CD4 + T 540 cell proliferation in humans (Okano et al., 2006). Furthermore, this inhibition may occur via 541 increased expression of COX2 and production of PGE2 by monocytes (Chen et al., 2011). 542 During chronic viral infection PGE2 can also directly suppress CD8 + T cells delaying viral 543 clearance (Chen et al., 2013). We now show that PGE2 can directly suppress the activation 544 and proliferation of human skin derived TRM cells. PGE2 may also induce the expansion and 545 increase the function of Foxp3 + Tregs (Baratelli et al., 2005; Sharma et al., 2005) explaining 546 why these cells increases in the skin during ageing (Vukmanovic-Stejic et al., 2008; 547 Vukmanovic-Stejic et al., 2013). 548 Elevated PGE2 concentrations are also found at the sites of chronic viral infection and virus-549 specific T cells in the liver of Hepatitis B infected individuals express the PGE2 receptor EP4 550 (Chen et al., 2015; Okano et al., 2006). The observation that PGE2 is found in tumour sites 551 prompted the suggestion that COX2 inhibitors may be useful in the treatment of colon cancer 552 and basal and squamous cell carcinoma (Pandeya et al., 2019; Steinbach et al., 2000). In 553 addition, PGE2 may promote immunosuppression by inducing the anti-inflammatory cytokine 554 IL-10 by mononuclear phagocytes (MacKenzie et al., 2013; Nakanishi and Rosenberg, 555 2013). We now show that the PGE2 receptor, EP4, is expressed by the majority of skin-556 resident TRM that facilitates the inhibition of these cells by this mediator. 557 Monocytes were historically regarded as precursors of macrophages, however more recent 558 data shows that they can be effector cells in their own right (Cros et al., 2010; Goritzka et al., 559 2015). We confirmed previous studies showing that monocytes can inhibit antigen-specific 560 responses (Sammicheli et al., 2016; Watanabe et al., 2017). Monocytes were shown to be 561 increased in the leukocyte infiltrates in the lungs of patients with severe COVID-19 562

Although CCR2 + monocytes can contribute to the 572 inflammatory environment in the skin, they are also actively involved in the resolution of 573 inflammation, for example in in the gut (Farro et al., 2017). Therefore, microenvironmental 574 cues may determine the function of monocytes that are recruited into different tissues. 575 Excessive inflammation has been shown to inhibit antigen-specific immunity (Pence et al., 576 2012) and reduce vaccination efficacy (Fourati et al., 2016; Muyanja et al., 2014; Parmigiani 577 et al., 2013). We have shown that the effects of inflammation on inhibiting immunity can be 578 reversed with a p38-MAPK inhibitor. Studies with other inhibitors of inflammation such as 579 mTOR inhibitor, rapamycin have shown that they can enhance the response to influenza 580 vaccination in older subjects by 20% (Mannick et al., 2014). Additionally, in non-human 581 ageing models, metformin and rapamycin can increase life-span and immune function 582 (Cabreiro et al., 2013; Miller et al., 2011; Neff et al., 2013). In addition, in a murine model of 583 breast cancer COX2 inhibitor could improve DC-based vaccine efficacy by increasing IFNγ 584 production and cytotoxic CD8 function (Basu et al., 2006). Therefore, many anti-585 inflammatory drugs are already licenced for use in humans or have been through phase III 586 clinical trials. Our observations with the p38-MAPK inhibitor Losmapimod provide a proof-of-587 principle demonstration that the efficacy of these drugs could be tested for their ability to 588 prevent the deleterious effects of inflammageing resulting in the enhancement of antigen-589 specific immunity in older humans in vivo. 590 RNA-seq samples.
